questions.text: Tip of ice berg phenomenon is most appropriately represented by
questions.solution:
Iceberg phenomenon is the graphic representation of variations in the manifestations of disease.

At one end of the disease spectrum are subclinical infections which are not ordinarily identified and at the other end are fatal illnesses. In the middle of the spectrum lie illnesses ranging in severity from mild to severe.

According to this concept, disease in a community may be compared with an iceberg. The floating tip of the iceberg represents what the physician sees in the community, i.e. , clinical cases. The vast submerged portion of the iceberg represents the hidden mass of disease, i.e., latent, inapparent, presymptomatic and undiagnosed cases and carriers in the community. The "waterline" represents the demarcation between apparent and inapparent disease.

Reference: Park's Preventive and social medicine, 27th Edition, Chapter - Concept Of Health & Disease.

questions.text: In a CHC area in a particular day, in which of the following diseases the prevalence may be zero though the incidence may be quite high in the area
questions.solution:
• Rabies is a disease where the incidence (new cases) can be high, but the prevalence (total number of cases) may be zero or very low at a given point in time due to the high mortality rate. Once symptoms appear, rabies progresses rapidly and is almost invariably fatal, meaning new cases do not accumulate over time, leading to a potentially zero prevalence even if new cases are being reported.
  • Prevalence is the total number of existing cases of a disease in a population at a given time.
  • Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a specified period.
  • In diseases with very high mortality like rabies, the prevalence may be zero if all new cases lead to death before they accumulate in the population.

Other options:

  • Ischemic Heart Disease and TB: Typically have higher prevalence due to chronic nature and longer disease duration.
  • Leprosy: While it has a slow progression, its prevalence would not typically be zero if incidence is high.

Reference: Park's Preventive and social medicine, 27th edition, Chapter Principles of Epidemiology & Epidemiology methods.

questions.text: Dengue in the community usually has 45-50 cases weekly, last week the case burden was 48 what type of disease is it in this community
questions.solution:
• Endemic: Refers to the constant presence and/or usual prevalence of a disease within a given geographic area. In this community, dengue has a steady case burden of 45-50 cases weekly, indicating that the disease is regularly present in the community at a relatively constant rate.
  • The term "hyperendemic" expresses that the disease is constantly present at a high incidence and/or prevalence rate and affects all age groups equally; and the term "holoendemic" a high level of infection beginning early in life and affecting most of the child population,
  • Epidemic: A sudden increase in the number of cases above what is normally expected; would require the current case burden to exceed the usual range plus 2 standard deviations.
  • Pandemic: An epidemic that occurs over a wide area, crossing international boundaries, affecting a large number of people. Examples are influenza pandemics and cholera pandemics.
  • Sporadic: Cases occur irregularly and infrequently, not in a predictable pattern. e.g., tetanus, herpes-zoster and meningococcal meningitis.

Reference: Park's Preventive and social medicine, 27th edition, Chapter Principles of Epidemiology & Epidemiology methods.

questions.text: A well of contaminated water resulting in an epidemic of acute watery diarrhoea is an example for which epidemic
questions.solution:
• Common source single exposure: Epidemics resulting from exposure to a common source that lasts for a short time, such as a single meal or event. After the exposure ends, the epidemic typically diminishes quickly.
  • Common source continuous exposure: Involves ongoing exposure to the same source, like contaminated water or food, leading to a prolonged outbreak.
  • Slow epidemic: Refers to a gradual increase in cases over time, often associated with diseases with long incubation periods.
  • Propagated epidemic: Occurs when the disease spreads from person to person, leading to a gradual rise in cases, often seen with infectious diseases where secondary cases result from direct transmission.

Reference: Park's Preventive and social medicine, 27th edition, Chapter Principles of Epidemiology & Epidemiology methods.

questions.text: In assessing the validity of screening test, those subjects who test positive with the screening test but test negative by the gold standard test are called
questions.solution:
In assessing the validity of a screening test, it's crucial to understand the terminology used to categorize the results. These terms are based on comparing the screening test results with those of a gold standard test, which is considered the most accurate diagnostic tool available.

c. FP (False Positive): These are cases where the screening test incorrectly identifies individuals as positive for the condition, but the gold standard test reveals that they do not actually have the disease or condition. This is often referred to as a "false alarm" or a Type I error. This is an important consideration in assessing the validity of a screening test because false positives can lead to unnecessary follow-up tests, treatments, and anxiety for patients.

Therefore, in the context of assessing the validity of a screening test, individuals who test positive with the screening test but test negative by the gold standard test are referred to as false positives (FP).

Why other options are not correct

  1. TP (True Positive): These are cases where the screening test correctly identifies individuals as positive for the condition, and the gold standard test confirms the presence of the disease or condition.
  2. TN (True Negative): These are cases where the screening test correctly identifies individuals as negative for the condition, and the gold standard test confirms the absence of the disease or condition.
  3. FN (False Negative): These are cases where the screening test incorrectly identifies individuals as negative for the condition, but the gold standard test shows that they actually have the disease or condition. This is known as a "missed diagnosis" or a Type II error.

Reference: Park's Preventive and social medicine, 27th EDITION Pg 156

questions.text: If we decide to keep 200mg/dl as the cut-off for distinguishing between diabetes and non-diabetes instead of 126mg/dl for fasting blood sugar then there will be an increase in
questions.solution:
Raising the cutoff value for distinguishing between diabetes and non-diabetes will increase specificity, resulting in fewer false positives.

When the cut-off for distinguishing between diabetes and non-diabetes is changed from 126 mg/dL to 200 mg/dL for fasting blood sugar, it means that individuals with fasting blood sugar levels between 126 mg/dL and 200 mg/dL, who were previously classified as diabetic, will now be classified as non-diabetic. This shift in the cut-off point will likely lead to an increase in specificity due to the following reasons:

  1. Specificity measures the ability of a diagnostic test to correctly identify individuals who do not have the disease (true negatives) out of all the individuals who truly do not have the disease (true negatives + false positives).
  2. By increasing the cut-off for defining diabetes to 200 mg/dL, individuals with fasting blood sugar levels between 126 mg/dL and 200 mg/dL, who were previously classified as diabetic, will now be classified as non-diabetic. This will lead to a decrease in the number of false positives (individuals incorrectly classified as diabetic when they are actually non-diabetic).
  3. As specificity is directly related to the number of true negatives and false positives, an increase in specificity means a decrease in false positives.

Explanation for why other options are wrong:

a. Sensitivity: Sensitivity refers to the ability of a test to correctly identify individuals with the condition (true positives) out of all the individuals who truly have the disease (true positives + false negatives).
Changing the cutoff value from 126 mg/dl to 200 mg/dl will likely decrease sensitivity because some individuals with diabetes who have blood sugar levels between these two cutoffs may now be classified as non-diabetic (false negatives).

b. False positives: False positives occur when individuals without the condition are incorrectly identified as having the condition when they are actually disease-free. Raising the cutoff value from 126 mg/dl to 200 mg/dl will likely decrease false positives, rather than increase them, leading to an increase in specificity, because fewer individuals with blood sugar levels between these two cutoffs will be classified as diabetic.

c. All the above: This option suggests that there will be an increase in sensitivity, specificity, and false positives. However, as explained above, sensitivity is likely to decrease, and false positives are likely to decrease, while specificity is likely to increase. Therefore, this option is not accurate.

Reference: Park's Preventive and social medicine, 27th EDITION Pg 155

questions.text: Analyse the following intervention done in a TB patient and estimate the levels of prevention- Sputum examination of suspects, BCG vaccination, hemi thoracotomy for widespread fibrosis of lung, avoiding overcrowding
questions.solution:
Sputum examination of suspects is secondary prevention, BCG vaccination is primary prevention, hemi thoracotomy for widespread fibrosis of the lung is tertiary prevention, and avoiding overcrowding is primordial prevention.

Explanation for why the other options are incorrect:

  1. Primary, Secondary, Tertiary, Primordial: This option is incorrect because it incorrectly orders the interventions. BCG vaccination is a primary prevention measure, sputum examination of suspects is secondary prevention, avoiding overcrowding is primordial prevention, and hemi thoracotomy for widespread fibrosis of the lung is tertiary prevention.
  2. Primordial, Primary, Secondary, Tertiary: This option is incorrect because it misidentifies the interventions. BCG vaccination is a primary prevention measure, sputum examination of suspects is secondary prevention, hemi thoracotomy for widespread fibrosis of the lung is tertiary prevention, but avoiding overcrowding is not primordial prevention.
  3. Primary, Tertiary, Primordial, Secondary: This option is incorrect because it misorders the interventions. BCG vaccination is primary prevention, hemi thoracotomy for widespread fibrosis of the lung is tertiary prevention, avoiding overcrowding is primordial prevention, but sputum examination of suspects is not secondary prevention.

Reference: Park's Preventive and social medicine, 27th EDITION Pg 48

questions.text: A Child with fever and rash presents with the following findings as shown in the image. What is the period of communicability of this disease?
questions.solution:
The disease in question appears to be measles, given the characteristic symptoms of fever and rash in a child. Measles is a highly contagious viral infection caused by the measles virus. Understanding the period of communicability is crucial for controlling the spread of the disease.

The correct answer, as you stated, is option (C): Four days before and four days after the appearance of the rash.

Explanation to why other options are not correct:

(A): Four days before and two days after the appearance of rash

This option is incorrect because measles is highly contagious, and the period of communicability extends beyond just two days after the rash appears. Measles can be transmitted through respiratory droplets and remains contagious for a significant period, hence the correct answer extends beyond two days after rash onset.

(B): Two days before and two days after the disappearance of rash

This option is incorrect because measles remains communicable for a period after the rash disappears. The measles virus can still be present in respiratory secretions and be transmitted to others even after the rash has resolved.

(D): Two days before and four days after the appearance of rash

This option is incorrect because it underestimates the duration of communicability before the appearance of the rash. Measles can be transmitted before the rash appears, so the period of communicability starts before the rash onset. Additionally, the duration after the rash should also be longer than four days, as measles remains contagious for a significant period after rash onset.

Therefore, option (C) is correct because it accurately reflects the period of communicability of measles, which extends four days before and four days after the appearance of the rash. This period covers the time when the infected person can spread the virus to others through respiratory secretions, which is crucial information for public health measures such as isolation and contact tracing.

Reference - Park's Preventive and social medicine, 27th EDITION Pg 165

questions.text: Select the most appropriate recommendation for HIV testing for Occupational Post Exposure Prophylaxis
questions.solution:
The most appropriate recommendation for HIV testing for Occupational Post Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) is: a. Immediately after exposure followed by HIV testing at the end of 3rd & 6th month.

a. Immediately after exposure followed by HIV testing at the end of 3rd & 6th month:This option aligns with standard recommendations for HIV testing after occupational exposure. Immediate testing after exposure allows for early detection of any potential HIV infection. Subsequent testing at the end of the 3rd and 6th months is crucial because HIV antibodies may take time to develop, and early negative results do not rule out infection. Testing at these intervals ensures comprehensive monitoring for HIV infection and allows for timely intervention if infection occurs.

Explanation to why other options are not correct:

b. Immediately after exposure followed by HIV testing at the end of 1st & 3rd month:While testing at the end of the 1st and 3rd months can be beneficial for early detection of HIV infection, waiting until the 6th month for the final test may delay diagnosis and treatment if infection occurs. The 6th month is a crucial period for HIV testing as it allows for the detection of late seroconversion cases. Therefore, option (b) may not provide adequate monitoring throughout the entire PEP period.

c. HIV testing at the end of completion of prophylaxis and also 2 months thereafter:Testing only at the end of PEP completion and 2 months thereafter may miss early seroconversion cases that occur before the completion of prophylaxis. Immediate testing after exposure is essential for early detection, and subsequent testing at the end of the 3rd and 6th months provides a more comprehensive monitoring approach.

d. Immediately after exposure followed by HIV testing at the end of completion of treatment:Testing only at the end of PEP completion may not be sufficient for early detection of HIV infection. As mentioned earlier, immediate testing after exposure allows for early detection, and subsequent testing at the end of the 3rd and 6th months provides comprehensive monitoring throughout the PEP period.

In summary, option (a) is the most appropriate recommendation for HIV testing for Occupational Post Exposure Prophylaxis as it includes immediate testing after exposure followed by subsequent testing at the end of the 3rd and 6th months, ensuring comprehensive monitoring for HIV infection.

Reference: Park's Preventive and social medicine, 27th EDITION Pg 405

questions.text: A resident doctor sustained a needlestick injury while sampling blood of a patient who is HIV positive. A decision is taken to offer him post exposure prophylaxis. Which of the following is the best recommendation?
questions.solution:
(C) Lamivudine + Tenofovir + Dolutegravir for 4 weeks:

This combination regimen includes two NRTIs (Lamivudine and Tenofovir) and one integrase strand transfer inhibitor (INSTI) (Dolutegravir). INSTIs are highly potent antiretroviral drugs with a favourable side effect profile. The combination of Lamivudine, Tenofovir, and Dolutegravir provides a potent three-drug regimen that targets different stages of the HIV life cycle, maximizing efficacy and reducing the risk of viral resistance.

Explanation to why other options are not correct:

(A) Zidovudine + Lamivudine for 4 weeks:

While Zidovudine and Lamivudine are both nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) commonly used in antiretroviral therapy (ART) for HIV infection, this regimen lacks a third drug that targets a different stage of the HIV life cycle. Additionally, Zidovudine may cause significant side effects, including hematologic toxicity, which may not be ideal for PEP.

(B) Lamivudine + Tenofovir + Efavirenz for 4 weeks:

While Lamivudine and Tenofovir are both NRTIs and are commonly used in ART, Efavirenz is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI). While Efavirenz is effective in treating HIV, it is not typically recommended for PEP due to its potential for neuropsychiatric side effects, particularly during the initial phase of treatment.

(D) Zidovudine + Lamivudine + Nevirapine for 4 weeks:

Similar to option (A), this regimen includes Zidovudine and Lamivudine, both of which are NRTIs. Nevirapine is an NNRTI commonly used in ART, but like Efavirenz, it is not typically recommended for PEP due to its potential for hepatotoxicity and skin reactions, particularly during the initial phase of treatment.

In summary, option (C) Lamivudine + Tenofovir + Dolutegravir for 4 weeks is the best recommendation for PEP for the resident doctor who sustained a needlestick injury while sampling blood from an HIV-positive patient. This regimen provides a potent three-drug combination with different mechanisms of action, maximizing efficacy and minimizing the risk of side effects. Options (A), (B), and (D) are not as suitable due to various factors such as lack of efficacy, potential toxicity, or suboptimal drug combinations.

Reference: Park's Preventive and social medicine, 27th EDITION Pg 405

questions.text: Which of the following is the national level system that provides annual national as well as state level reliable estimates of fertility and mortality?
questions.solution:
Sample Registration System (SRS) (Option D):

  • The Sample Registration System (SRS) is a national-level system in India that provides annual reliable estimates of fertility (birth rates) and mortality (death rates) at both national and state levels.
  • SRS operates under the Office of the Registrar General & Census Commissioner, India, and is designed to provide continuous demographic data through a sample survey methodology.
  • It covers a representative sample of households across the country and collects data on births, deaths, and other vital events to estimate fertility and mortality rates, which are crucial for demographic analysis and policy planning.

Why the other options are not correct:

  • Civil Registration System (Option A):
    • The Civil Registration System (CRS) is a method of recording vital events such as births, deaths, marriages, and divorces through a legal system administered by local governments.
    • While the CRS is essential for maintaining accurate demographic records, it typically does not provide annual national and state-level estimates of fertility and mortality rates in India.
  • Census (Option B):
    • The census is a comprehensive enumeration of the population conducted at regular intervals, usually every ten years.
    • While the census provides valuable demographic data, including information on population size and distribution, it is not specifically designed to provide annual estimates of fertility and mortality rates.
  • Ad-hoc Survey (Option C):
    • Ad-hoc surveys refer to one-time or occasional surveys conducted for specific research or data collection purposes.
    • While ad-hoc surveys may provide useful information on various topics, they are not typically used to generate annual national and state-level estimates of fertility and mortality on a continuous basis.

In summary, the Sample Registration System (SRS) is the correct answer as it is specifically designed to provide annual national and state-level estimates of fertility and mortality in India. Unlike the other options, SRS operates through a systematic sample survey methodology, allowing for the continuous collection and analysis of demographic data essential for policy planning and decision-making.

Reference: Park's Preventive and social medicine, 27th EDITION Pg 969

choices.text: DR begins to decline, while the BR remains unchanged

questions.text: True about late expanding stage of demographic cycle
questions.solution:
The late expanding stage of the demographic cycle is characterized by specific demographic trends as a country progresses through economic and social development.

c. DR declines still further and BR tends to fall:

This statement accurately describes the trends seen in the late expanding stage. As countries progress through this stage, both birth rates and death rates continue to decline, albeit at different rates. Improved healthcare, education, and access to family planning services often lead to a decline in both birth and death rates during this stage, with birth rates eventually tending to fall more rapidly than death rates.

Why the other options are not correct:

a. BR is lower than DR:

This statement is not true for the late expanding stage. In this stage, birth rates (BR) typically remain relatively high, often higher than death rates (DR), contributing to population growth. So, BR being lower than DR would not be characteristic of this stage.

b. DR begins to decline, while the BR remains unchanged:

While it is true that death rates (DR) may begin to decline during the late expanding stage due to improvements in healthcare, sanitation, and living standards, birth rates (BR) also tend to decline, although not necessarily simultaneously. The statement implies that BR remains unchanged, which is not typical for this stage. Birth rates usually start to fall, although they may still be higher than death rates.

d. High BR and high DR:

This statement might describe an earlier stage of demographic transition, such as the early expanding stage or even the pre-transitional stage. However, in the late expanding stage, while birth rates may still be relatively high compared to developed countries, death rates begin to decline, resulting in a lower overall mortality rate compared to earlier stages. So, high death rates are not characteristic of the late expanding stage.

In summary, option "c" is true for the late expanding stage because it accurately reflects the ongoing decline in death rates and the tendency for birth rates to fall as a country progresses through this stage of demographic transition.

Reference: Park's Preventive and social medicine, 27th EDITION Pg 554

questions.text: A 37 weeks pregnant woman attends an antenatal clinic at a PHC. She has not had any antenatal care till now. The best approach here regarding TT immunisation would be
questions.solution:
The best approach regarding TT immunization for a 37-week pregnant woman attending an antenatal clinic at a Primary Health Centre (PHC) who has not had any antenatal care till now would be option A: Give a dose of TT & explain to her that it will not protect the newborn & she should take the second dose after 4 weeks even if she delivers in the meantime.

  • This option is the best approach because administering Tetanus Toxoid (TT) vaccine at this stage of pregnancy can provide some level of protection against tetanus for the mother during delivery and for the newborn.
  • Even though the full course of TT vaccination requires multiple doses for optimal protection, giving at least one dose of TT at this late stage of pregnancy can still offer some benefit.
  • By explaining to the woman that this dose will not fully protect the newborn and advising her to take the second dose after 4 weeks regardless of whether she delivers in the meantime, healthcare providers can ensure that she receives appropriate follow-up care for tetanus prevention.

Why the other options are not correct:

Option B: Do not waste the TT vaccine as it would anyhow be of no use in this pregnancy:

  • This option is not recommended because administering TT vaccine, even at this late stage, can still provide some level of protection against tetanus for the mother during delivery.
  • While one dose may not fully protect the newborn, it can still offer some benefit to the mother, and it sets the stage for follow-up vaccination after delivery.

Option C: Given one dose of TT, explain it will not be useful for this pregnancy:

  • Simply giving the TT vaccine without providing proper information about its limitations and follow-up care may lead to confusion or misunderstanding on the part of the pregnant woman.
  • It's essential to educate the woman about the purpose and timing of TT vaccination to ensure that she understands the importance of follow-up care.

Option D: Give anti-tetanus immunoglobulin along with the TT vaccine:

  • Administering anti-tetanus immunoglobulin is not typically indicated for routine antenatal care unless there is a specific indication, such as a tetanus-prone wound or a history of incomplete or inadequate TT vaccination.
  • Using immunoglobulin alongside TT vaccine in this scenario would not be appropriate without a specific indication for its use.

In summary, option A is the best approach because it provides some level of protection against tetanus for the mother and sets the stage for follow-up vaccination after delivery, while also ensuring that the woman receives proper information about the limitations of the vaccine and the need for additional doses.

Reference: Park's Preventive and social medicine, 27th EDITION Pg 604

questions.text: A 10-month-old child weighing 8 kg has Bitot spots in both eyes. Which of the following is the most appropriate schedule to prescribe vitamin A?
questions.solution:
a) 1 lakh IU on day 0, 1, and 14:This option provides a total of 3 doses of 1 lakh IU (International Units) of vitamin A, spaced over a period of 14 days. This schedule is appropriate for treating moderate vitamin A deficiency, as indicated by the presence of Bitot spots. It follows the WHO-recommended dosage schedule for treating vitamin A deficiency in children.

Bitot spots are a clinical sign of vitamin A deficiency and indicate a deficiency in the child. Vitamin A supplementation is necessary to address this deficiency and prevent further complications.

Why the other options are not correct:

b) 2 lakh IU on day 0, 1, and 14:This option provides a higher total dose of 6 lakh IU of vitamin A over 14 days. While this dose may be appropriate for severe cases of vitamin A deficiency, it is higher than the standard recommended dose for treating moderate deficiency, as indicated by Bitot spots. Such a high dose may increase the risk of adverse effects and is not necessary in this case.

c) 1 lakh IU on day 0, 1:This option provides only 2 doses of 1 lakh IU of vitamin A, without a follow-up dose on day 14. The recommended schedule for treating moderate vitamin A deficiency, as indicated by Bitot spots, includes a follow-up dose on day 14 to ensure adequate supplementation and replenishment of vitamin A stores.

d) 2 lakh IU on day 0, 1:Similar to option b), this option provides a higher total dose of 4 lakh IU of vitamin A over 2 days without a follow-up dose on day 14. Again, this dose is higher than the standard recommended dose for treating moderate deficiency and may not be necessary in this case.

In summary, option a) (1 lakh IU on day 0, 1, and 14) is the most appropriate choice because it follows the WHO-recommended dosage schedule for treating moderate vitamin A deficiency, as indicated by Bitot spots. Options b), c), and d) provide either higher doses or incomplete schedules, which may not be suitable for treating moderate deficiency in a 10-month-old child. Therefore, option a) is the correct answer.

Reference : Park's Preventive and social medicine, 27th EDITION Pg 731

questions.text: A farmer whose predominant diet is maize has presented with hyperpigmented skin lesion around the neck. What history will you ask in this patient?
questions.solution:
The hyperpigmented skin lesions around the neck, often referred to as "necklace sign" or "casal necklace," are characteristic dermatological manifestations of pellagra. Pellagra is a nutritional deficiency disease caused by a deficiency of niacin (vitamin B3) and/or tryptophan, an amino acid that can be converted to niacin in the body. Maize is a staple food in many regions, particularly in areas where pellagra is prevalent, and it is deficient in niacin unless treated with alkali, such as lime.

a. Diarrhoea and dementia:This option is correct. Pellagra is characterized by the classic triad of symptoms, known as the "4 Ds": dermatitis (hyperpigmented skin lesions, particularly in areas exposed to sunlight), diarrhoea, dementia, and death if untreated. Therefore, it is crucial to ask about symptoms such as diarrhoea and cognitive impairment (dementia) in a patient presenting with hyperpigmented skin lesions characteristic of pellagra.

Why the other options are not correct:

b. Trauma:Trauma would not typically lead to hyperpigmented skin lesions around the neck unless there is a specific injury or irritation causing localized skin changes. Pellagra, on the other hand, is a systemic nutritional deficiency disease that manifests with characteristic skin lesions in areas exposed to sunlight.

c. Family history:While family history is important in assessing the risk of certain conditions, it is less relevant in the context of pellagra, which is primarily caused by dietary deficiencies rather than genetic factors.

d. Insect bite:Insect bites would not typically lead to hyperpigmented skin lesions resembling the "necklace sign" of pellagra. Pellagra is caused by nutritional deficiencies, particularly niacin deficiency, and manifests with characteristic skin changes, gastrointestinal symptoms, and neurological manifestations.

In summary, option (a) is the most appropriate choice as it reflects the classic symptoms associated with pellagra and is relevant to the patient's presentation of hyperpigmented skin lesions around the neck. Options (b), (c), and (d) are less relevant in this context.

Reference : Park's Preventive and social medicine, 27th Edition, Pg 734

questions.text: Arrange the following stages of family cycle in chronological sequence
questions.solution:
The correct answer is D. Formation, Extension, Complete extension, Contraction, Complete contraction, Dissolution.

D. Formation, Extension, Complete extension, Contraction, Complete contraction, Dissolution:This sequence begins with formation, progresses to extension, then complete extension. Next, it moves to contraction, followed by complete contraction, and concludes with dissolution. This order aligns with the typical stages of the family cycle, starting with the formation of the family unit, followed by periods of expansion, contraction, and eventually dissolution.

Why the other options are not suitable:

A. Formation, Extension, Complete extension, Dissolution, Contraction, Complete contraction: This sequence does not follow the logical progression of the family cycle. The stages of extension and contraction are out of order, and dissolution typically occurs after contraction, not before it.

B. Formation, Extension, Contraction, Complete extension, Complete contraction, Dissolution: This sequence starts with formation and includes extension and contraction but then introduces "complete extension" and "complete contraction" before dissolution. The terms "complete extension" and "complete contraction" are not commonly used stages in the family cycle.

C. Formation, Contraction, Complete contraction, Extension, Complete extension, Dissolution: This sequence starts with formation and moves to contraction before introducing "complete contraction." Then, it jumps to extension, followed by "complete extension," and ends with dissolution. The placement of "complete contraction" and "complete extension" disrupts the logical progression of the family cycle.

Option D provides the most accurate and logically ordered sequence of stages in the family cycle, making it the correct choice.

Reference: Park's Preventive and social medicine, 27th EDITION Pg 797

questions.text: Which one of the following methods is used for the estimation of chlorine demand of water
questions.solution:
The correct answer is B. Horrock's apparatus.

Horrock's apparatus, is specifically designed for the estimation of chlorine demand in water. It consists of a series of cups containing varying amounts of chlorine, which are added to a water sample until all the chlorine is consumed by reacting with the substances in the water. The amount of chlorine required to satisfy the demand, as indicated by the colour change in the cups, is a measure of the chlorine demand of the water sample.

Why the other options are not suitable:

A. Chlorometer: A chlorometer is a device used to measure the concentration of chlorine in water, typically using colorimetric methods. It is not used for the estimation of chlorine demand, which refers to the amount of chlorine needed to achieve a desired level of disinfection in water.

C. Berkefeld filter: A Berkefeld filter is a type of gravity filter used for water filtration. It is not used for the estimation of chlorine demand in water.

D. Double pot method: The double pot method is a technique used to estimate the total coliform count in water samples. It involves incubating water samples in a double pot apparatus and observing bacterial growth. It is not used for the estimation of chlorine demand.

In summary, option B (Horrock's apparatus) is the correct choice because it is the method used for the estimation of chlorine demand in water. The other options are not relevant to chlorine demand estimation.

Reference: Park's Preventive and social medicine, 27th EDITION Pg 855

questions.text: As per the most common classification of triage system that is internationally accepted, the colour code that indicates high priority treatment or transfer is
questions.solution:
Triage is a system used in disaster and emergency situations to prioritize medical treatment based on the severity of injuries and the likelihood of survival. The most common classification system internationally accepted for triage uses colour codes to categorize patients into different priority levels.

Explanation of each colour code and its corresponding priority level:

A. Black: This colour code is typically used to indicate deceased or expectant patients who have suffered severe injuries or medical conditions incompatible with life. Patients tagged with black are not expected to survive and are not provided with immediate medical treatment.

B. Yellow: The yellow colour code is used to designate patients with non-life-threatening injuries or illnesses that require medical attention but are not considered urgent. These patients may have minor injuries or stable medical conditions that do not require immediate treatment, allowing medical personnel to focus on patients with more severe conditions.

C. Red: The red colour code indicates patients with severe or life-threatening injuries or medical conditions that require immediate medical attention. These patients have critical injuries or conditions that, if left untreated, could rapidly deteriorate or result in death. Red-tagged patients are prioritized for prompt medical treatment and transfer to medical facilities capable of providing advanced care.

D. Blue: The blue colour code is typically used to designate patients with minor injuries or medical conditions that do not require immediate treatment. These patients may have minor cuts, bruises, or complaints that can be addressed after higher priority patients have been stabilized and treated.

In summary, the correct answer is C. Red because it indicates high priority treatment or transfer for patients with severe or life-threatening injuries or conditions. The other colour codes (black, yellow, and blue) represent different priority levels based on the severity of injuries or medical conditions, with red being the highest priority level for immediate medical intervention.

Reference: Park's Preventive and social medicine, 27th EDITION Pg 923

questions.text: A 11 years old child presented with fever and sore throat. To diagnose the condition a throat swab was obtained and sent for culture. After collection of throat swab should be discarded in which colour coded bag according to biomedical waste management?
questions.solution:
(a) Blue bag: Blue bags are typically used for the disposal of non-sharp, non-infectious biomedical waste, such as disposable gowns, gloves, and other personal protective equipment. Throat swabs collected for culture may contain infectious material and should be disposed of in a container designated for infectious waste.

(b) Red bag: Red bags are specifically designated for the disposal of infectious waste that poses a risk of infection to healthcare workers, patients, or the environment. Throat swabs collected for culture fall under this category as they may contain potentially pathogenic microorganisms.

(d) White bag: White bags are often used for the disposal of non-hazardous, non-infectious waste materials. Throat swabs collected for culture contain potentially infectious material and should not be discarded in a white bag.

The correct disposal method for the throat swab used for culture is the yellow bag. Yellow bags are reserved for infectious or pathological waste, including items contaminated with blood, bodily fluids, or potentially infectious microorganisms. Throat swabs collected for culture fall into this category and should be disposed of accordingly to prevent the spread of infection.

Reference: Park's Preventive and social medicine, 27th EDITION Pg 919

questions.text: A cardiologist wants to study the effect of an antihypertensive drug. He notes down the initial systolic BP (mmHg) of 50 patients and then administer the drug on them. After a week's treatment, he again measures the BP. Which is the most appropriate statistical test of significance to test the change in BP.
questions.solution:
The most appropriate statistical test to analyze the change in blood pressure (BP) before and after treatment in the same group of patients is the Paired t-test

a) Paired t-test:

The paired t-test is designed to compare the means of two related groups (in this case, the initial BP measurements before treatment and the BP measurements after treatment for the same individuals). It evaluates whether the mean difference between paired observations (before and after treatment) is statistically significant. It is particularly useful when the sample size is small (<30) and the data are normally distributed, which is often the case in medical research.

Explanation as to why the other options are not correct :

b) Unpaired t-test:

The unpaired t-test is used to compare the means of two independent groups.In this scenario, the same group of patients is measured before and after treatment, so they are not independent groups. Therefore, the unpaired t-test is not appropriate.

c) Analysis of Variance (ANOVA):

ANOVA is used to compare the means of three or more independent groups.It is not suitable for comparing the means of paired observations within the same group.

d) Chi-square test:

The chi-square test is used to analyze categorical data, typically to test for independence between two categorical variables. It is not suitable for analyzing continuous numerical data like blood pressure measurements.

In summary, the most appropriate statistical test for comparing the change in blood pressure before and after treatment within the same group of patients is the paired t-test because it is specifically designed for this type of analysis, taking into account the paired nature of the observations.

Reference: Park's Preventive and social medicine, 27th EDITION Pg 980

Reference: Biostatistics: Basic Concepts and Methodology for the Health Sciences pg

questions.text: In UNICEF's GOBI campaign, 'O' stands for:

UNICEF's GOBI (Growth monitoring, Oral rehydration therapy, Breastfeeding, and Immunization) campaign was launched in the early 1980s to address key issues related to child health and well-being in developing countries. Each letter in the acronym represents a critical intervention or component of child health promotion.

Explanation for why not the other options:

A. Oral contraceptives:

  • While oral contraceptives are important for family planning and reproductive health, they are not part of the UNICEF GOBI campaign, which focuses on child health and development rather than family planning.

C. Obesity:

D. Occupational hazards:
